item.title: 1. Personal Good Ways
item.dc:creator: vasileioskorompilias@gmail.com
item.description:
Personal Good Ways are methods related to our Continence.

<p>The post 1. Personal Good Ways first appeared on Crisis Resolutions.</p>
item.content:encoded:
How to practice Continence

Overview

Personal Good Ways are methods related to our Continence. They express the 1st Level of our flexibility, sensibility, sustainability, accessibility, and capability.

Continence is the ability to control one’s urges or desires.

Mnemonic: Right Hand

Each of our fingers have been assigned with a different sub-level. They have also been associated with a colour from the visible light spectrum.

The association with the Right hand has been based on our Brain Hemispheres and their predominant functionality. So, for most cases you may leave the list as is.

Left-handed people, and leftwards-reading cultures may find it more intuitive to switch to the other hand as their mnemonic for this set, but it is not mandatory.

Step 1. Personal Flexibility

Continence is a practice of personal good ways that involves flexibility in selfhood, childhood, parenthood, siblinghood, and spousehood.

Definitions

  • Flexibility: The ability to adjust and adapt to changing circumstances or conditions.
  • Selfhood: A person’s identity or sense of individuality.
  • Childhood: The period of a person’s life when they are a child.
  • Parenthood: The state of being a parent.
  • Siblinghood: The relationship between siblings.
  • Spousehood: The state of being married or in a long-term relationship with a spouse.

Step 2. Personal Sensibility

Continence is a practice of good ways that involves sensitivity to capacity, charge, current, resistance, and power.

Definitions

  • Sensibility: The capacity to perceive, feel, or be conscious of something.
  • Capacitance: The ability of a device or material to store an electrical charge.
  • Charge: An imbalance of electric charge between two points.
  • Current: The flow of electric charge in an electrical circuit.
  • Resistivity: The measure of a material’s resistance to the flow of electric current.
  • Power: The rate at which energy is transferred, used, or transformed.

Step 3. Personal Sustainability

Continence is a personal practice that involves sustaining infinity, intensity, density, resistance, and conductivity.

Definitions

  • Sustainability: The ability to support and maintain oneself without depleting natural resources.
  • Infinity: An unlimited or unmeasurable amount.
  • Intensity: The degree or strength of a feeling, emotion, or sensation.
  • Density: The mass of a substance per unit volume.
  • Resistance: The ability of a material or device to oppose the flow of electric current, heat, or sound.
  • Conductivity: The ability of a material or device to allow the flow of electric current.

Step 4. Personal Accessibility

Continence is a personal practice that involves accessibility to probability, correlation, curvature, clustering, and causality.

Definitions

  • Accessibility: The ability to access or use something, such as a resource or service.
  • Probability: The likelihood that an event will occur.
  • Correlation: A statistical measure of the relationship between two variables.
  • Curvature: The degree to which a geometric figure deviates from being flat.
  • Clustering: The grouping of objects or events that are close to each other in terms of distance, time, or relationship.
  • Causality: The relationship between two events in which one event causes the other.

Step 5. Personal Capability

Continence is a personal practice that involves capability through potential action, kinetic action, radiant action, thermal action, and chemical action.

Definitions

  • Capability: The capacity to do or achieve something.
  • Potential Action: The ability to cause change or influence the outcome of an event.
  • Kinetic Action: The ability to move or cause motion.
  • Radiant Action: The ability to emit or absorb radiation.
  • Thermal Action: The ability to transfer or absorb heat.
  • Chemical Action: The ability to cause or undergo a chemical reaction.

List

Personal Good Ways – Continence:

  • through Flexibility of:
    • Selfhood
    • Childhood
    • Parenthood
    • Siblinghood
    • Spousehood
  • through Sensibility of:
    • Capacitance
    • Charge
    • Current
    • Resistivity
    • Power
  • through Sustainability of:
    • Infinity
    • Intensity
    • Density
    • Resistance
    • Conductivity
  • through Accessibility of:
    • Probability
    • Correlation
    • Curvature
    • Clustering
    • Causality
  • through Capability of:
    • Potential Action
    • Kinetic Action
    • Radiant Action
    • Thermal Action
    • Chemical Action

Summary

Continence is a personal good way that is achieved through the flexibility of selfhood, childhood, parenthood, siblinghood, spousehood, the sensibility of capacitance, charge, current, resistivity, power, the sustainability of infinity, intensity, density, resistance, conductivity, the accessibility of probability, correlation, curvature, clustering, causality, and the capability of potential action, kinetic action, radiant action, thermal action, and chemical action.

<p>The post 1. Personal Good Ways first appeared on Crisis Resolutions.</p>

item.title: 3. Practical Good Ways
item.dc:creator: vasileioskorompilias@gmail.com
item.description:
Practical Good Ways are methods related to our Presence.

<p>The post 3. Practical Good Ways first appeared on Crisis Resolutions.</p>
item.content:encoded:
How to practice Presence

Overview

Practical Good Ways are methods related to our Presence. They express the 6th Level of our flexibility, sensibility, sustainability, accessibility, and capability.

Mnemonic: Palms Touching

Each of our fingers have been assigned with a different sub-level. They have also been associated with a color from the visible light spectrum.

By Palms Touching we mean that this family of Ways are the essence of the previous couple and next two Sets. Processing by Both of our Brain Hemispheres has been accounted here.

In fact, you may only learn this 3rd Set, and you would be good with all the rest.

Step 1. Practical Flexibility

Practical Good Ways may be expressed by being present through flexibility of intuition, tensions, behaviors, relations, and emotions.

Definitions

  • Flexibility: The ability to adjust and adapt to changing circumstances or conditions.
  • Intuition: The ability to understand something instinctively, without the need for conscious reasoning.
  • Tensions: A state of mental or emotional strain resulting from adverse or very demanding circumstances.
  • Behaviors: The way in which one acts or conducts oneself, especially toward others.
  • Relations: The way in which two or more people, groups, countries, etc., talk to, behave toward, and deal with each other.
  • Emotions: A strong feeling deriving from one’s circumstances, mood, or relationships with others.

Step 2. Practical Sensibility

Practical Good Ways may also be expressed by being present through sensibility of purpose, honesty, generosity, consensus, and love.

Definitions

  • Sensibility: The capacity to perceive, feel, or be conscious of something.
  • Purpose: The reason for which something is created or done.
  • Honesty: The quality of being honest, fairness, and sincerity.
  • Generosity: Willingness to give more of something, such as money, than is strictly necessary or expected.
  • Consensus: General agreement or consensus among a group of people.
  • Love: An intense feeling of deep affection.

Step 3. Practical Sustainability

Practical Good Ways may also be expressed by being present through sustainability of indefinite capacity, intense magnitudes, dense coverages, resistant formations, and conductive conversions.

Definitions

  • Sustainability: The ability to support and maintain oneself without depleting natural resources.
  • Indefinite Capacity: The ability to function indefinitely without exhaustion or loss of power.
  • Intense Magnitudes: Great power and force of intensity.
  • Dense Coverages: A large area of coverage that is closely packed together.
  • Resistant Formations: Structures that are resistant to change or alteration.
  • Conductive Conversions: The process of converting energy from one form to another.

Step 4. Practical Accessibility

Practical Good Ways may also be expressed by being present through accessibility of experience, attentiveness, intention, simulation, and stimulation.

Definitions

  • Accessibility: The ability to access or use something, such as a resource or service.
  • Experience: Knowledge or skill that is gained by doing something.
  • Attentiveness: The quality of being alert and watchful.
  • Intention: An aim or plan.
  • Simulation: The imitation of the functioning of one system with another system.
  • Stimulation: The action of arousing or stirring someone or something into activity.

Step 5. Practical Capability

Practical Good Ways may also be expressed by being present through capability of potential reaction, kinetic reaction, radiant reaction, thermal reaction, and chemical reaction.

Definitions

  • Capability: The capacity to do or achieve something.
  • Potential Reaction: A response to a stimulus that is possible but not yet actualized.
  • Kinetic Reaction: A reaction that involves the motion of particles in a system.
  • Radiant Reaction: A reaction that involves the emission of light or other energy waves.
  • Thermal Reaction: A reaction that involves the transfer of heat energy.
  • Chemical Reaction: A reaction that involves the breaking and forming of chemical bonds.

List

Practical Good Ways – Presence

  • through Flexibility of:
    • Intuition
    • Tensions
    • Behaviors
    • Relations
    • Emotions
  • through Sensibility of:
    • Purpose
    • Honesty
    • Generosity
    • Consensus
    • Love
  • through Sustainability of:
    • Indefinite Capacity
    • Intense Magnitudes
    • Dense Coverages
    • Resistant Formations
    • Conductive Conversions
  • through Accessibility of:
    • Experience
    • Attentiveness
    • Intention
    • Simulation
    • Stimulation
  • through Capability of:
    • Potential Reaction
    • Kinetic Reaction
    • Radiant Reaction
    • Thermal Reaction
    • Chemical Reaction

Summary

Practical Good Ways may be expressed in terms of Flexibility, Sensibility, Sustainability, Accessibility, and Capability. Our Flexibility includes the ability to adjust and adapt to changing circumstances or conditions, such as intuition, tensions, behaviors, relations, and emotions. Our Sensibility includes having a purpose, being honest, generous, having consensus, and exhibiting love. Sustainability includes the ability to support and maintain oneself without depleting natural resources, having indefinite capacity, intense magnitudes, dense coverages, resistant formations, and conductive conversions. Accessibility includes the ability to access or use something, such as a resource or service, experiencing something, being attentive, having an intention, simulating something, and stimulating something. Capability includes the capacity to do or achieve something, such as potential reactions, kinetic reactions, radiant reactions, thermal reactions, and chemical reactions.

<p>The post 3. Practical Good Ways first appeared on Crisis Resolutions.</p>

item.title: 7. Empirical Good Ways
item.dc:creator: vasileioskorompilias@gmail.com
item.description:
Mental Good Ways are methods related to our Conscience.

<p>The post 7. Empirical Good Ways first appeared on Crisis Resolutions.</p>
item.content:encoded:
How to practice Science

Overview

Empirical Good Ways are methods related to the Science of doing something. They express the 7th Level of our flexibility, sensibility, sustainability, accessibility, and capability.

Mnemonic: Pelvis Movements

By Empirical we mean, they are based on experience.

In this Set, Body Movements have been assigned as a Mnemonic technique, and the Pelvis as our Center with its 6 Freedoms of Movement in Space.

All other Good Ways Sets are 5-fold with 25 ways each, while the 7th Set is the only 6-fold one defining 30 ways.

The association with the Rightward and Leftward movements has been based on our Brain Hemispheres and their predominant functionality. So, for most cases you may leave the list as is.

Left-handed people, and leftwards-reading cultures may find it more intuitive to switch the third part of the list with the fourth, and the fourth with the third, but it is not mandatory.

Step 1. Empirical Flexibility

Science is an Empirical Good Way helping us practice our flexibility of: freedom, diversity, inclusion, fitness, party, and wellbeing.

Our Empirical Flexibility, a quality of Upward Movement (as when we stand up), is the essence of our Freedom. When experienced as Forward Movement (as when we walk), it is expressed as Diversity. This Diversity concerns matters of Inclusion and Fitness, as a result of Leftward and Rightward Movements respectively (as when our brain hemispheres share different responsibilities). Backward Movements are associated with the ability to Party (as when we stay still), and Downward with Wellbeing (as when we lay down and rest).

Definitions

  • Flexibility: The ability to adjust and adapt to changing circumstances or conditions.
  • Freedom: The power or being oneself.
  • Diversity: The state of being varied and made up of different elements or types.
  • Inclusion: The action or state of including or of being included within a group or structure.
  • Fitness: The condition of being generally fit and healthy.
  • Party: A Group or an organized social gathering.
  • Wellbeing: The state of being fulfilled and happy.

Step 2. Empirical Sensibility

Empirical Good Ways are scientific methods that involve practicing Sensibility through input feedback, indexing evaluation, output feedback, modeling classification, and memory allocation to determine the best course of action.

Definitions

  • Sensibility: The capacity to perceive, feel, or be conscious of something.
  • Input Feedback: Receiving input signals from the external environment.
  • Indexing Evaluation: Assessing the quality of our observations by associating them to indices.
  • Output Feedback: Converting our input into output signals and sending them back to the external environment.
  • Memory Allocation: Allocating memory resources to store our feedback for later use.
  • Modeling Classification: Determining how our feedback will be used for predictive or analytical purposes.

Step 3. Empirical Sustainability

Science is a sustainable practice that seeks to promote economic liberty, ecophysiological equality, ecological solidarity, ecospheric peace, ecotypic order, and ecosystemic governance.

Definitions

  • Sustainability: The ability to support and maintain oneself without depleting natural resources.
  • Economic Liberty: The liberty of being oneself through wise management of source and resources.
  • Ecophysiological Equality: The state of equal access to resources or opportunities regardless of physical or physiological characteristics.
  • Ecological Solidarity: Practicing in ways that benefit the planet and its inhabitants.
  • Ecospheric Peace: The state of being in harmony with nature and the environment.
  • Ecotypic Order: An organized social structure that is based on the natural order of the environment.
  • Ecosystemic Governance: Maintaining wellbeing between life and its environment.

Step 4. Empirical Accessibility

Science provides accessible levels of empowerment, support for topics, composition of recipes, documentation of journals, adaptation of challenges, and coexistence of rituals.

Definitions

  • Accessibility: The ability to access or use something, such as a resource or service.
  • Levels Empowerment: The act of providing people with the resources and abilities needed to increase their power and control of their lives.
  • Topics Support: Assistance given to those who are researching and discussing a particular subject.
  • Recipes Composition: The process of creating a combination of ingredients and techniques to produce a synthesis.
  • Journals Documentation: Keeping detailed records of events, thoughts, or observations for future reference.
  • Challenges Adaptation: Adjusting to new or changing circumstances in order to survive and succeed.
  • Rituals Coexistence: Practices or ceremonies that are repeated and shared by members of a community or culture, often to mark transitions or celebrate special occasions.

Step 5. Empirical Capability

Science is the empirical genesis of self-reflection, practice of sentience, mimesis of self-autonomy, growth of simplicity, and investigation of symmetry, and producing wealth as inheritance of variety.

Definitions

  • Capability: The capacity to do or achieve something.
  • Self-Reflection Genesis: A process of reflecting on one’s own thoughts, beliefs, and actions.
  • Sentience Practice: The practice of being aware or conscious of one’s own thoughts, feelings, and emotions.
  • Self-Autonomy Mimesis: The ability to act and make decisions independently, even when faced with difficult or complex situations.
  • Simplicity Growth: The process of increasing simplicity and reducing complexity in order to facilitate greater understanding and clarity.
  • Symmetry Investigation: The exploration and examination of patterns, shapes, and forms in order to discover underlying order and structure.
  • Variety Inheritance: The transfer of traits, characteristics, and abilities from one generation to the next.

List

Empirical Good Ways – Science

  • through Flexibility of:
    • Freedom
    • Diversity
    • Inclusion
    • Fitness
    • Party
    • Wellbeing
  • through Sensibility of:
    • Input Feedback
    • Indexing Evaluation
    • Output Feedback
    • Modeling Classification
    • Memory Allocation
  • through Sustainability of:
    • Economic Liberty
    • Ecophysiological Equality
    • Ecological Solidarity
    • Ecospheric Peace
    • Ecotypic Order
    • Ecosystemic Governance
  • through Accessibility of:
    • Levels Empowerment
    • Topics Support
    • Recipes Composition
    • Journals Documentation
    • Challenges Adaptation
    • Rituals Coexistence
  • through Capability of:
    • Self-Reflection Genesis
    • Sentience Practice
    • Self-Autonomy Mimesis
    • Simplicity Growth
    • Symmetry Investigation
    • Variety Inheritance

Summary

Science is a method of empirical inquiry that helps us maintain flexibility of freedom, diversity, inclusion, fitness, partying, and wellbeing. By analyzing input feedback, indexing evaluation, output feedback, modeling classification, and memory allocation, we can sustain economic liberty, ecophysiological equality, ecological solidarity, ecospheric peace, ecotypic order, and ecosystemic governance. Then, through cooperation in matters of accessibility levels empowerment, topics support, recipes composition, journals documentation, challenges adaptation, and rituals coexistence we can refine our capability for self-reflection genesis, sentience practice, self-autonomy mimesis, simplicity growth, symmetry investigation, and variety inheritance.

<p>The post 7. Empirical Good Ways first appeared on Crisis Resolutions.</p>

item.title: 8. Vital Good Ways
item.dc:creator: vasileioskorompilias@gmail.com
item.description:
Vital Good Ways are methods related to the Essence of doing something.

<p>The post 8. Vital Good Ways first appeared on Crisis Resolutions.</p>
item.content:encoded:
How to practice Essence

Overview

Vital Good Ways are methods related to the Essence of doing something. They express the 8th Level of our flexibility, sensibility, sustainability, accessibility, and capability.

Mnemonic: Time

These qualities has been associated with the fundamental measures of Time, and help us to ensure that our lives are filled with joy, peace, and happiness.

By practicing Vital Good Ways, we can look to the past for inspiration and create a brighter future. Through this, we can enjoy every day, and better appreciate the essence of our holidays.

Our Vital Good Ways can bring us closer together and provide us with the tools we need to lead a better life.

Step 1. Vital Flexibility

Essence is a Vital Good Way helping us practice our flexibility of: origin, crisis, resolutions, journey, and unity.

Our Vital Flexibility, a quality of our past, is the essence of our origin. When experienced today, it is expressed as crisis. This crisis has a sense of tomorrow, its future resolution. All crisis are meant to be resolved in nature. These resolutions become our everyday journey, and when they become part of our common sense of unity, we turn them into holidays.

Definitions

  • Flexibility: The ability to adjust and adapt to changing circumstances or conditions.
  • Origin: Where something comes from.
  • Crisis: Our ability to think.
  • Resolutions: Solutions to a problem.
  • Journey: A trip or process.
  • Unity: When all the parts work together in harmony.

Step 2. Vital Sensibility

Our Sensibility, a remnant vitality of our past, is the essence of our model. When experienced today, it is expressed as events. These events give us a sense of tomorrow, which signifies their future resolution. All events are meant to be resolved in nature. These model events become our everyday model behaviors, and when they become part of our common sense of structure, we turn them into holidays.

Definitions

  • Sensibility: The capacity to perceive, feel, or be conscious of something.
  • Model refers to a representation of something, such as a person, object, or concept.
  • Events are occurrences or happenings.
  • Model Events are occurrences or happenings that are related to a model.
  • Model Behaviors are the actions of a model.
  • Structure is the way something is organized or put together.

Step 3. Vital Sustainability

Our Sustainability, a remnant vitality of our past, is the essence of our home. When experienced today, it is expressed as a hello. This hello we tell to each other gives us a sense of tomorrow, which is its future habitat. All hello are meant to find habitats in nature. These help become our everyday habits, and when they become part of our common sense of habitats, we turn them into holidays.

Definitions

  • Sustainability: The ability to support and maintain oneself without depleting natural resources.
  • Home: A base.
  • (Saying) Hello: Expressing a basic greeting.
  • Help: To give assistance or support.
  • Habits: A repeated behavior or action.
  • Habitats: A regular environment.

Step 4. Vital Accessibility

Our Accessibility, a remnant vitality of our past, is the essence of our galleries. When experienced today, they are expressed as lists. These lists give us a sense of tomorrow, which is their future grouped in tables. All lists are meant to turn to be grouped in tables in nature. These tables become our everyday boards, and when they become part of our common sense, they turn into our calendar, and state our holidays.

Definitions

  • Accessibility: The ability to access or use something, such as a resource or service.
  • Galleries are collections of items.
  • Lists are items arranged in a specific order.
  • Tables are grids of information.
  • Boards are collections of items.
  • Calendars are used to keep track of dates.

Step 5. Vital Capability

Our Capability, the remnant vitality of our past, is the essence of our strategy layer. When experienced today, it is expressed as our application layer. This application layer gives us a sense of tomorrow, which is the future of our business layer. All application layers are meant to turn to a business layer in nature. This business layer becomes our everyday technology layer, and when it becomes part of our common sense, it turns into our implementation layer, defining our holidays.

Definitions

  • Capability: The capacity to do or achieve something.
  • The Strategy Layer is the highest level of planning, where the overall goals of a project are set.
  • The Application Layer is the layer where the actual applications are built and run.
  • The Business Layer is the layer that deals with the business aspects of the project, such as customer service and marketing.
  • The Technology Layer is the layer that deals with the technical aspects of the project, such as hardware, software, and networking.
  • The Implementation Layer is the layer that deals with the actual implementation of the project, such as coding and testing.

List

Vital Good Ways – Essence

  • through Flexibility of:
    • Origin
    • Crisis
    • Resolutions
    • Journey
    • Unity
  • through Sensibility of:
    • Model
    • Events
    • Model Events
    • Model Behaviors
    • Structure
  • through Sustainability of:
    • Home
    • Hello
    • Help
    • Habits
    • Habitats
  • through Accessibility of:
    • Galleries
    • Lists
    • Tables
    • Boards
    • Calendars
  • through Capability of:
    • Strategy Layer
    • Application Layer
    • Business Layer
    • Technology Layer
    • Implementation Layer

Summary

Vital Good Ways are the cornerstone of our lives, allowing us to experience joy, peace, and happiness. By integrating these into our daily lives, we can make them part of our common sense, and turn them into holidays. Through these holidays, we can appreciate our past and create a brighter future. By embracing Vital Good Ways, we can ensure that our lives are full of flexibility, sensibility, sustainability, accessibility, and capability. With these qualities, we can ensure that our lives are filled with joy, peace, and happiness.

<p>The post 8. Vital Good Ways first appeared on Crisis Resolutions.</p>

item.title: 6. Mutual Good Ways
item.dc:creator: vasileioskorompilias@gmail.com
item.description:
Mutual Good Ways are methods related to our Defense.

<p>The post 6. Mutual Good Ways first appeared on Crisis Resolutions.</p>
item.content:encoded:
How to practice Defense

Overview

Mutual Good Ways are methods related to our Defense. They express the 6th Level of our flexibility, sensibility, sustainability, accessibility, and capability.

Mnemonic: Head

Our Head is being approached here as our mnemonic device, with our Ears, Hair, Mouth, Eyes, and Nose associated with the Defense of our Character, Intelligence, Services, Community, and Systems respectively.

Step 1. Mutual Flexibility

Defense is a Mutual Good Way helping us practice our flexibility of: Character, Intelligence, Services, Community, and Systems.

Our Mutual Flexibility, a quality also shared by our Ears (shared input, from opposed sides), is the first Defense of our Character. Our Intelligence is a bit chaotic as our Hair. Our Services have a passive and active state as our Mouth. Our Community share observations like our Eyes do, and our Systems in general are recursive as our breath, filtering information as a Defense mechanism.

Definitions

  • Flexibility: The ability to adjust and adapt to changing circumstances or conditions.
  • Character: The qualities and attributes of the Self.
  • Intelligence: The ability to acquire and apply knowledge and skills through Crisis.
  • Services: A Resolution performed by one party that benefits another.
  • Community: A group of people with common interests or characteristics.
  • Systems: A Family of related components that interact to form a complex whole.

Step 2. Mutual Sensibility

Mutual Good Ways of Defense means finding ways to protect yourself and others by using common sense in the areas of Management, Curation, Interaction, Cooperation, and Operation.

Definitions

  • Sensibility: The capacity to perceive, feel, or be conscious of something.
  • Management: The act of managing or supervising something.
  • Curation: The act of caring for, organizing, and maintaining something.
  • Interaction: The mutual or reciprocal influence between two or more entities.
  • Cooperation: Working together to the same end.
  • Operation: A process or series of actions taken to achieve a result.

Step 3. Mutual Sustainability

Mutual Defense is a way of protecting each other by making sure that the things we need to survive, like Utility (electricity, water, etc.), Mobility (transportation), Hospitality (places to stay), Commodity (goods and services) and Identity (who we are) are sustainable.

Definitions

  • Sustainability: The ability to support and maintain oneself without depleting natural resources.
  • Utility: The quality of being useful or functional.
  • Mobility: The ability to move or be moved freely and easily.
  • Hospitality: The friendly and generous reception and entertainment of guests, visitors, or strangers.
  • Commodity: A product that can be bought and sold.
  • Identity: The fact of being who or what a person or thing is.

Step 4. Mutual Accessibility

Mutual Defense is a Good Way of protecting each other through Accessibility deriving from the Stasis, Thesis, Synthesis, Hypothesis, and Systasis of ourselves, our ideas, and of others.

Definitions

  • Accessibility: The ability to access or use something, such as a resource or service.
  • Stasis: A state of balance or equilibrium; a period of inactivity or stagnation.
  • Thesis: A statement or theory that is put forward as a premise to be maintained or proved.
  • Synthesis: The combination of components or elements to form a connected whole.
  • Hypothesis: An explanation or a foundation for something else.
  • Systasis: The condition or state of being.

Step 5. Mutual Capability

Defense means working together through our mutual capability of teaching, researching, deploying, designing, and having a shared philosophy.

Definitions

  • Capability: The capacity to do or achieve something.
  • Pedagogy: The method and practice of teaching, especially as an academic subject or theoretical concept.
  • Research: The systematic investigation into and study of materials and sources in order to establish facts and reach new conclusions.
  • Deployment: The method of delivering a product or service to its end users.
  • Design: The process of creating a plan or specification for the construction of an object, system or measurable human interaction.
  • Philosophy: The study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

List

Mutual Good Ways – Defense

  • through Flexibility of:
    • Character
    • Intelligence
    • Services
    • Community
    • Systems
  • through Sensibility of:
    • Management
    • Curation
    • Interaction
    • Cooperation
    • Operation
  • through Sustainability of:
    • Utility
    • Mobility
    • Hospitality
    • Commodity
    • Identity
  • through Accessibility of:
    • Stasis
    • Thesis
    • Synthesis
    • Hypothesis
    • Systasis
  • through Capability of:
    • Pedagogy
    • Research
    • Deployment
    • Design
    • Philosophy

Summary

Defense is a family of Mutual Good Ways helping us protect ourselves and others by being flexible, sensible, sustainable, accessible, and capable. Defense Flexibility includes character, intelligence, services, community, and systems. Sensibility includes management, curation, interaction, cooperation, and operation. Sustainability includes utility, mobility, hospitality, commodity, and identity. Accessibility includes stasis, thesis, synthesis, hypothesis, and systasis. Capability includes pedagogy, research, deployment, design, and philosophy.

<p>The post 6. Mutual Good Ways first appeared on Crisis Resolutions.</p>

item.title: 4. Social Good Ways
item.dc:creator: vasileioskorompilias@gmail.com
item.description:
Social Good Ways are methods related to our Sense.

<p>The post 4. Social Good Ways first appeared on Crisis Resolutions.</p>
item.content:encoded:
How to practice Sense

Overview

Social Good Ways are methods related to our Sense. They express the 6th Level of our flexibility, sensibility, sustainability, accessibility, and capability.

Mnemonic: Left Hand

  • Each of our fingers have been assigned with a different sub-level. They have also been associated with a color from the visible light spectrum.
  • The association with the Left hand has been based on our Brain Hemispheres and their predominant functionality. So, for most cases you may leave the list as is.
  • Left-handed people, and leftwards-reading cultures may find it more intuitive to switch to the other hand as their mnemonic for this set, but it is not mandatory.

Step 1. Social Flexibility

Practicing Social Good Ways involves being flexible through detachment, perfection, imagination, imperfection, and memory.

Definitions

  • Flexibility: The ability to adjust and adapt to changing circumstances or conditions.
  • Detachment: The ability to detach oneself from emotions or circumstances and maintain an objective view.
  • Perfection: The state of being free from flaws or defects; absolute accuracy and precision.
  • Imagination: The ability to form mental images or concepts of external objects not present to the senses.
  • Imperfection: The state or quality of being imperfect; the lack of completeness or accuracy.
  • Memory: The mental capacity or faculty of retaining and reviving facts, events, and impressions, or of recalling or recognizing previous experiences.

Step 2. Social Sensibility

Social Good Ways also involve having sensibility through hearing, touch, taste, vision, and smell.

Definitions

  • Sensibility: The capacity to perceive, feel, or be conscious of something.
  • Hearing: The ability to perceive sound or respond to sound waves.
  • Touch: The ability to perceive or sense physical contact or texture.
  • Taste: The ability to distinguish different flavors or sensations in the mouth.
  • Vision: The ability to perceive or detect light and form images.
  • Smell: The ability to perceive or detect odors.

Step 3. Social Sustainability

Social Good Ways may be practiced through a Sense of sustainability of capacity, magnitude, coverage, formation, and convertibility.

Definitions

  • Sustainability: The ability to support and maintain oneself without depleting natural resources.
  • Capacity: The amount of something that can be contained or accommodated.
  • Magnitude: The size, importance, or influence of something.
  • Coverage: The extent to which something covers, affects, or includes something else.
  • Formation: The action or process of forming or creating something.
  • Convertibility: The ability to be changed or converted into something else.

Step 4. Social Accessibility

Social Good Ways may also involve expressing a sense of accessibility to courage, receptiveness, altruism, truthfulness, and wisdom.

Definitions

  • Accessibility: The ability to access or use something, such as a resource or service.
  • Courage: The quality of mind or spirit that enables a person to face difficulty, danger, pain, etc., without fear; bravery.
  • Receptiveness: The ability or willingness to receive or accept ideas, suggestions, or information.
  • Altruism: Unselfish concern for the welfare of others; selflessness.
  • Truthfulness: The quality of being truthful; honesty.
  • Wisdom: The quality of having experience, knowledge, and good judgment; the quality of being wise.

Step 5. Social Capability

Social Good Ways may also be practiced through a sense of capability for ethical conduct, effort, resolve, view, and livelihood.

Definitions

  • Capability: The capacity to do or achieve something.
  • Ethical Conduct: Behavior that is consistent with moral obligations and duties.
  • Ethical Effort: Making a concerted effort to do the right thing.
  • Ethical Resolve: Making a commitment to act in an ethical and responsible manner.
  • Ethical View: Considering the ethical implications of decisions and actions.
  • Ethical Livelihood: Earning a living in a way that is consistent with ethical principles.

List

Social Good Ways – Sense

  • through Flexibility of:
    • Detachment
    • Perfection
    • Imagination
    • Imperfection
    • Memory
  • through Sensibility of:
    • Hearing
    • Touch
    • Taste
    • Vision
    • Smell
  • through Sustainability of:
    • Capacity
    • Magnitude
    • Coverage
    • Formation
    • Convertibility
  • through Accessibility of:
    • Courage
    • Receptiveness
    • Altruism
    • Truthfulness
    • Wisdom
  • through Capability of:
    • Ethical Conduct
    • Ethical Effort
    • Ethical Resolve
    • Ethical View
    • Ethical Livelihood

Summary

This document outlines five ways to practice social good: Flexibility, Sensibility, Sustainability, Accessibility, and Capability. Flexibility involves being able to detach oneself from emotions or circumstances and maintain an objective view, as well as having perfection, imagination, imperfection, and memory. Sensibility involves hearing, touch, taste, vision, and smell. Sustainability involves having capacity, magnitude, coverage, formation, and convertibility. Accessibility involves courage, receptiveness, altruism, truthfulness, and wisdom. Lastly, capability involves ethical conduct, effort, resolve, view, and livelihood.

<p>The post 4. Social Good Ways first appeared on Crisis Resolutions.</p>

item.title: 5. Ethical Good Ways
item.dc:creator: vasileioskorompilias@gmail.com
item.description:
Ethical Good Ways are methods related to our Absence.

<p>The post 5. Ethical Good Ways first appeared on Crisis Resolutions.</p>
item.content:encoded:
How to practice Absence

Overview

Ethical Good Ways are methods related to our Absence. They express the 6th Level of our flexibility, sensibility, sustainability, accessibility, and capability.

Mnemonic: Left Foot

Each of our fingers have been assigned with a different sub-level. They have also been associated with a color from the visible light spectrum.

The association with the Left foot has been based on our Brain Hemispheres and their predominant functionality. So, for most cases you may leave the list as is.

If you switched hands for the previous sets, it is mandatory to also change feet as your mnemonic.

Step 1. Ethical Flexibility

Ethical Good Ways may be expressed as Absence through Flexibility of Non-Detachment, Non-Perfection, Non-Imagination, Non-Imperfection, Non-Memory.

Definitions

  • Flexibility: The ability to adjust and adapt to changing circumstances or conditions.
  • Non-Detachment: The ability to remain connected and engaged with a situation or experience, even when it is difficult or uncomfortable.
  • Non-Perfection: The acceptance of imperfection as a positive characteristic and the understanding that perfection is impossible to achieve.
  • Non-Imagination: The ability to think outside the box and come up with creative solutions that are not pre-defined or predetermined.
  • Non-Imperfection: The understanding that mistakes and flaws are part of life and the willingness to accept them and learn from them.
  • Non-Memory: The ability to let go of past experiences and memories in order to move forward and create a better future.

Step 2. Ethical Sensibility

Ethical Good Ways may be expressed as Absence through Sensibility to Non-Hearing, Non-Touch, Non-Taste, Non-Vision, Non-Smell.

Definitions

  • Sensibility: The capacity to perceive, feel, or be conscious of something.
  • Non-Hearing: The capacity to be aware of and respond to sounds without needing to actually hear them.
  • Non-Touch: The capacity to be aware of and respond to physical contact without needing to actually feel it.
  • Non-Taste: The capacity to be aware of and respond to taste without needing to actually taste it.
  • Non-Vision: The capacity to be aware of and respond to visual information without needing to actually see it.
  • Non-Smell: The capacity to be aware of and respond to smells without needing to actually smell them.

Step 3. Ethical Sustainability

Ethical Good Ways may be expressed as Absence from the Sustainability of Non-Capacity, Non-Magnitude, Non-Coverage, Non-Formation, Non-Convertibility.

Definitions

  • Sustainability: The ability to support and maintain oneself without depleting natural resources.
  • Non-Capacity: The capacity to be self-sustaining without the need to overconsume resources.
  • Non-Magnitude: The capacity to be independent and self-sufficient without the need to rely on external sources.
  • Non-Coverage: The capacity to be resilient and adaptive without the need to be uniform and homogeneous.
  • Non-Formation: The capacity to be flexible and dynamic without the need for rigidity and stagnation.
  • Non-Convertibility: The capacity to be open and accepting without the need to conform or be restricted.

Step 4. Ethical Accessibility

Ethical Good Ways may be expressed as Absence from the Accessibility of Non-Courage, Non-Receptiveness, Non-Altruism, Non-Truthfulness, Non-Wisdom.

Definitions

  • Accessibility: The ability to access or use something, such as a resource or service.
  • Non-Courage: The capacity to take action without the need to be fearless.
  • Non-Receptiveness: The capacity to be open to new ideas and experiences without the need to agree or accept them.
  • Non-Altruism: The capacity to be generous and giving without the need to be selfless.
  • Non-Truthfulness: The capacity to be honest and genuine without the need to be absolute.
  • Non-Wisdom: The capacity to be wise and thoughtful without the need to be omniscient.

Step 5. Ethical Capability

Ethical Good Ways may be practiced through absence deriving from observations over the capability of Non-Ethical Conduct, Non-Ethical Effort, Non-Ethical Resolve, Non-Ethical View and Non-Ethical Livelihood.

Definitions

  • Capability: The capacity to do or achieve something.
  • Non-Ethical Conduct: The capacity to behave in an ethical manner without the need to be perfect.
  • Non-Ethical Effort: The capacity to strive for ethical behavior without the need to be infallible.
  • Non-Ethical Resolve: The capacity to persist in ethical behavior without the need for perfection.
  • Non-Ethical View: The capacity to see the world through an ethical lens without the need to be absolutely right or wrong.
  • Non-Ethical Livelihood: The capacity to live ethically without the need to be completely selfless or unselfish.

List

Ethical Good Ways – Absence

  • through Flexibility of:
    • Non-Detachment
    • Non-Perfection
    • Non-Imagination
    • Non-Imperfection
    • Non-Memory
  • through Sensibility of:
    • Non-Hearing
    • Non-Touch
    • Non-Taste
    • Non-Vision
    • Non-Smell
  • through Sustainability of:
    • Non-Capacity
    • Non-Magnitude
    • Non-Coverage
    • Non-Formation
    • Non-Convertibility
  • through Accessibility of:
    • Non-Courage
    • Non-Receptiveness
    • Non-Altruism
    • Non-Truthfulness
    • Non-Wisdom
  • through Capability of:
    • Non-Ethical Conduct
    • Non-Ethical Effort
    • Non-Ethical Resolve
    • Non-Ethical View
    • Non-Ethical Livelihood

Summary

Being Ethical, through the Good Way of Absence, involves being flexible without the need for detachment, perfection, imagination, imperfection, memory. Moreover it involves being sensible without the need for hearing, touch, taste, vision, smell, sustainable without capacity, magnitude, coverage, formation, convertibility, accessible without courage, receptiveness, altruism, truthfulness, wisdom, and capable through sensibility over the existence of non-ethical conduct, non-ethical effort, non-ethical resolve, non-ethical view, and non-ethical livelihood.

<p>The post 5. Ethical Good Ways first appeared on Crisis Resolutions.</p>

item.title: 2. Mental Good Ways
item.dc:creator: vasileioskorompilias@gmail.com
item.description:
Mental Good Ways are methods related to our Conscience.

<p>The post 2. Mental Good Ways first appeared on Crisis Resolutions.</p>
item.content:encoded:
How to practice Conscience

Overview

Mental Good Ways are methods related to our Conscience. They express the 6th Level of our flexibility, sensibility, sustainability, accessibility, and capability.

Conscience is a person’s sense of right and wrong, and their willingness to do what is good.

Mnemonic: Right Foot

Each of our fingers have been assigned with a different sub-level. They have also been associated with a color from the visible light spectrum.

The association with the Right foot has been based on our Brain Hemispheres and their predominant functionality. So, for most cases you may leave the list as is.

If you switched hands for the previous sets, it is mandatory to also change feet as your mnemonic.

Step 1. Mental Flexibility

Conscience is a beneficial mental exercise that can be developed through the flexibility of not being self-centered, child-like, a parent, a sibling, or a spouse.

Definitions

  • Flexibility: The ability to adjust and adapt to changing circumstances or conditions.
  • Non-Selfhood: The practice of not being self-centered.
  • Non-Childhood: The practice of not being child-like.
  • Non-Parenthood: The practice of not being parent-like.
  • Non-Siblinghood: The practice of not being sibling-like.
  • Non-Spousehood: The practice of not being spouse-like.

Step 2. Mental Sensibility

Conscience can also be developed through the sensibility of not having capacitance, charge, current, resistivity, or power.

Definitions

  • Sensibility: The capacity to perceive, feel, or be conscious of something.
  • Non-Capacitance: The practice of not having capacitance.
  • Non-Charge: The practice of not having charge.
  • Non-Current: The practice of not having current.
  • Non-Resistivity: The practice of not having resistivity.
  • Non-Power: The practice of not having power.

Step 3. Mental Sustainability

Conscience can be cultivated by avoiding infinite intensity, density, resistance, and conductivity.

Definitions

  • Sustainability: The ability to support and maintain oneself without depleting natural resources.
  • Non-Infinity: The practice of not sustaining infinity.
  • Non-Intensity: The practice of not sustaining intensity.
  • Non-Density: The practice of not sustaining density.
  • Non-Resistance: The practice of not sustaining resistance.
  • Non-Conductivity: The practice of not sustaining conductivity.

Step 4. Mental Accessibility

Conscience can be exercised through access to non-probability, non-correlation, non-curvature, non-clustering, and non-causality.

Definitions

  • Accessibility: The ability to access or use something, such as a resource or service.
  • Non-Probability: The absence of probability.
  • Non-Correlation: The absence of a relationship between two or more variables.
  • Non-Curvature: The absence of a curved shape.
  • Non-Clustering: The absence of grouping together.
  • Non-Causality: The absence of a cause-and-effect relationship.

Step 5. Mental Capability

Conscience can also be developed through the capability of not having potential action, kinetic action, radiant action, thermal action, or chemical action.

Definitions

  • Capability: The capacity to do or achieve something.
  • Non-Potential Action: The practice of not having potential action.
  • Non-Kinetic Action: The practice of not having kinetic action.
  • Non-Radiant Action: The practice of not having radiant action.
  • Non-Thermal Action: The practice of not having thermal action.
  • Non-Chemical Action: The practice of not having chemical action.

List

Mental Good Ways – Conscience

  • through Flexibility of:
    • Non-Selfhood
    • Non-Childhood
    • Non-Parenthood
    • Non-Siblinghood
    • Non-Spousehood
  • through Sensibility of:
    • Non-Capacitance
    • Non-Charge
    • Non-Current
    • Non-Resistivity
    • Non-Power
  • through Sustainability of:
    • Non-Infinity
    • Non-Intensity
    • Non-Density
    • Non-Resistance
    • Non-Conductivity
  • through Accessibility of:
    • Non-Probability
    • Non-Correlation
    • Non-Curvature
    • Non-Clustering
    • Non-Causality
  • through Capability of:
    • Non-Potential Action
    • Non-Kinetic Action
    • Non-Radiant Action
    • Non-Thermal Action
    • Non-Chemical Action

Summary

Mental good ways are based on being flexible in terms of non-selfhood, non-childhood, non-parenthood, non-siblinghood, non-spousehood, sensible about non-capacitance, non-charge, non-current, non-resistivity, non-power, sustainable in matters of non-infinity, non-intensity, non-density, non-resistance, non-conductivity, accessible to non-probability, non-correlation, non-curvature, non-clustering, non-causality, and capable in terms of non-potential action, non-kinetic action, non-radiant action, non-thermal action, and non-chemical action.

<p>The post 2. Mental Good Ways first appeared on Crisis Resolutions.</p>
